configuration.name: mc-item-022398373670876026
configuration.title: Unit Starter: Identifying Factors Related to Reproduction
configuration.stem: Ecologists study relationships between environmental factors and reproductive success by gathering and analyzing data. This graph shows the average number of eggs laid, called clutch size, for titmouse birds during years with different amounts of caterpillars available to eat.

options.name: mc-opt-item-028151441155932844
options.label: The number of caterpillars available to titmouse birds in the English countryside changes from year to year due to changes in average rainfall, as well as the presence of other species that compete for food.
options.imageAlt: This graph shows that an increase in caterpillars per square mile causes an increase in bird clutch size. Click on the graph to learn more about this relationship.

options.name: mc-opt-item-06761015402153134x1
options.label: An unexpected environmental factor, such as a drought or fire, can reduce caterpillar populations. Birds struggling to find food must use more energy to find food, leaving less energy to produce eggs.
options.imageAlt: This graph shows that an increase in caterpillars per square mile causes an increase in bird clutch size. Click on the graph to learn more about this relationship.

options.name: LII-023241183896362827
options.label: An abundance of caterpillars can result from higher than average rainfall or a low number of competitors. With a larger food supply, birds may lay more eggs, but the eggs may be smaller.
options.imageAlt: This graph shows that an increase in caterpillars per square mile causes an increase in bird clutch size. Click on the graph to learn more about this relationship.
